questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
For the following reaction

2A + 3B $$\to$$ 3C + 4D

expression for rate of reaction is
questions.explanation:
The rate of a chemical reaction can be expressed in terms of the rate of change of concentration of any reactant or product. According to the given reaction:

$$ 2A + 3B \to 3C + 4D $$

The rate of this reaction can be expressed as the rate of disappearance of the reactants A or B, or as the rate of appearance of the products C or D. Since A is being consumed, its concentration will decrease over time and because B, C, and D are all involved in the reaction in different stoichiometric ratios, their rates of consumption or production will be proportional to their stoichiometric coefficients.

The general relation between the rate of the reaction and the rate of change of concentration of any species is given by:

$$ \text{Rate} = -\frac{1}{\text{stoichiometric coefficient}} \frac{d[\text{reactant}]}{dt} = \frac{1}{\text{stoichiometric coefficient}} \frac{d[\text{product}]}{dt} $$

For reactant A with a stoichiometric coefficient of 2:

$$ \text{Rate} = -\frac{1}{2} \frac{d[A]}{dt} $$

For reactant B with a stoichiometric coefficient of 3:

$$ \text{Rate} = -\frac{1}{3} \frac{d[B]}{dt} $$

For product C with a stoichiometric coefficient of 3:

$$ \text{Rate} = \frac{1}{3} \frac{d[C]}{dt} $$

For product D with a stoichiometric coefficient of 4:

$$ \text{Rate} = \frac{1}{4} \frac{d[D]}{dt} $$

So the correct options that match the expression for the rate of reaction based on the appearance of products C and D are:

Option C: $$ {1 \over 3}{{d[C]} \over {dt}} $$

Option D: $$ {1 \over 4}{{d[D]} \over {dt}} $$

Note that when expressing the rate with respect to the reactants (A and B), the rate must include a negative sign because their concentrations decrease as the reaction proceeds. For products (C and D), the rate is positive because their concentrations increase.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: If Rydberg constant is same for all elements, the angular momentum and energy of Li2+ of which orbital is equal to angular momentum and energy of 1 s-orbital of hydrogen atom?
questions.explanation:
Energy for H-like atom, $$(E) \propto {{{Z^2}} \over {{n^2}}}$$

For hydrogen, Z = 1, n = 1

For lithium Z = 3, n = ?

$$\therefore$$ For same energy,

$${E_H} = {E_{Li}} \Rightarrow {{Z_H^2} \over {n_H^2}} = {{Z_{Li}^2} \over {n_{Li}^2}}$$

$$\therefore$$ $$n_{Li}^2 = {{Z_{Li}^2 \times n_H^2} \over {Z_H^2}} \Rightarrow n_{Li}^2 = {{{3^2} \times 1} \over 1}$$

$$n_{Li}^2 = 3$$

While angular momentum (nh/2$$\pi$$) is independent of atomic number.

$$\therefore$$ For 3s-orbital of lithium atom, energy and angular momentum is equal to that of 1s orbital of hydrogen atom.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: The correct order of bond order in SO2, SO3, SO$$_4^{2 - }$$, SO$$_3^{2 - }$$ is
questions.explanation:
Bond order for the various compounds are as follows

for SO2,

Number of bonds = 4

Number of (SO) groups = 2

$$\therefore$$ Bond order $$ = {4 \over 2} = 2$$

For SO3,

Number of bonds = 6

Number of (SO) groups = 3

$$\therefore$$ Bond order $$ = {6 \over 3} = 2$$

For SO$$_4^{2 - }$$,

Number of bonds = 6

Number of (SO) groups = 4

$$\therefore$$ Bond order $$ = {6 \over 4} = 1.5$$

For SO$$_3^{2 - }$$,

Number of bonds = 4

Number of (SO) groups = 3

$$\therefore$$ Bond order $$ = {4 \over 3} = 1.33$$

Hence, correct order is $$S{O_2} = S{O_3} > SO_4^{2 - } > SO_3^{2 - }$$.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: For the complete combustion of ethanol, $${C_2}{H_5}OH(I) + 3{O_2}(g) \to 2C{O_2}(g) + 3{H_2}O(I)$$, the amount of heat produced as measured in bomb calorimeter is 1364.47 kJ mol$$-$$1 at 25$$^\circ$$C. Assuming ideality the enthalpy of combustion, $$\Delta$$HC, for the reaction will be (R = 8.314 JK$$-$$1 mol$$-$$1)
questions.explanation:
$${C_2}{H_5}OH(I) + 3{O_2}(g) \to 2C{O_2}(g) + 3{H_2}O(I)$$

$$\Delta U = - 1364.47$$ kJ/mol,

$$ \Rightarrow \Delta {n_g} = - 1$$

T = 25$$^\circ$$C = 298 K

$$\therefore$$ $$\Delta H = \Delta U + \Delta {n_g}RT$$

$$\Delta H = - 1364.47 + {{ - 1 \times 8314 \times 298} \over {1000}}$$

[Here, value of R in unit of J must be converted into kJ]

$$ = - 1364.47 - 2.4776 = - 1366.95$$ kJ/mol

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: The incorrect expression among the following is
questions.explanation:
(a) $$\Delta$$G = $$\Delta$$H $$-$$ T $$\Delta$$S

For a system, total entropy change is $$\Delta$$Stotal,

$$\Delta$$Htotal = 0

$$\therefore$$ $$\Delta$$Gsystem = $$-$$T$$\Delta$$Stotal

$$\therefore$$ $${{\Delta {G_{system}}} \over {\Delta {S_{total}}}} = - T$$

Thus, (a) is true,

(b) For isothermal reversible process, $$\Delta$$E = 0.

By first law of thermodynamics,

$$\Delta$$E = q $$\times$$ W

$$\therefore$$ Wreversible = $$-$$q = $$-$$$$\int_{{V_t}}^{{V_f}} {p\,dV} $$

Wreversible = $$ - nRT\ln {{{V_f}} \over {{V_t}}}$$

Thus, (b) is true.

(c) $$\Delta G^\circ = \Delta H^\circ - T\Delta S^\circ $$

$$\Delta G^\circ = - nRT\ln \,K = - RT\ln K$$ (for n = 1)

$$\therefore$$ $$ - RT\ln K = \Delta H^\circ - T\Delta S^\circ $$

$$\therefore$$ $$\ln K = - \left( {{{\Delta H^\circ - T\Delta S^\circ } \over {RT}}} \right)$$

Thus, (c) is incorrect.

(d) $$\Delta G^\circ = - RT\ln K$$

$$\therefore$$ $$\ln K = - {{\Delta G^\circ } \over {RT}}$$ $$\therefore$$ $$K = {e^{ - \Delta G^\circ /RT}}$$

Thus, (d) is also true.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: The relative lowering of vapour pressure of a dilute aqueous solution containing non-volatile solute is 0.0125. The molality of the solution is about
questions.explanation:
According to Raoult's law, relative lowering of vapour pressure is equal to mole fraction of solute,

$$\therefore$$ $${{p - {p_s}} \over p} = {n \over {n + N}} = {w \over m}{{w/m} \over {{w \over m} + {W \over M}}} \Rightarrow {w \over m} < < < {W \over M}$$

$$\therefore$$ $${{p^\circ - {p_s}} \over {p^\circ }} = {{w/m} \over {{W \over M}}} = {w \over m} \times {M \over W}$$

$$0.0125 = {{w \times 18} \over {m \times W}} \Rightarrow {w \over {mW}} = {{0.0125} \over {18}}$$

$$ = {{Weight\,of\,solute\,(w) \times 1000} \over {Molar\,mass\,of\,solute\,(m) \times Weight\,of\,{H_2}O(W)}}$$

Now, molality $$m = {{0.0125} \over {18}} \times 1000 = 0.69 \approx 0.7$$

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: Equal masses of methane and oxygen are mixed in an empty container at 25$$^\circ$$C. The fraction of the total pressure exerted by oxygen is
questions.explanation:
Suppose the equal mass of methane and oxygen, w = 1 g

Mole fraction of oxygen = $$ = {{w/32} \over {{w \over {32}} + {w \over {16}}}} = {{1/32} \over {{3 \over {32}}}} = {1 \over 3}$$

Let, the total pressure = p

Pressure exerted by oxygen (partial pressure)

$$ = {\chi _{{O_2}}} \times {p_{total}} = p \times {1 \over 3}$$

$$\therefore$$ The fraction of total pressure exerted by oxygen is $${1 \over 3}p$$.

questions.content: The molar conductivities of KCl, NaCl and KNO3 are 152, 128 and 111 S cm2 mol$$-$$1 respectively. What is the molar conductivity of NaNO3?

Sum of molar conductivity of reactant = Sum of molar conductivity of products

$$\Lambda ^\circ (NaN{O_3}) = \Lambda _m^o(NaCl) + \Lambda _m^o(KN{O_3}) - \Lambda _m^o(KCl)$$

$$KCl - NaCl = - \Lambda _m^oKCl - \Lambda _m^o(NaCl) = 24$$

Molar conductivities of KNO3 = 111

Molar conductivities of NaNO3 = 111 $$-$$ 24 = 87 S cm2 mol$$-$$1

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the word which best expresses the meaning of the underlined word in the sentence.
questions.content: Decay is an $$\underline {immutable} $$ factor of human life.
questions.explanation:
Option C :

unchangeable

Explanation :

The word 'immutable' means unchanging over time or unable to be changed. When used in the sentence "Decay is an immutable factor of human life," it emphasizes that decay (or aging, deterioration over time) is a constant, unchanging aspect of human life that we cannot alter or avoid.

Let's examine the other options :

Option A : Important - While decay might be considered an important factor in human life due to its inevitability, this doesn't capture the meaning of 'immutable,' which has more to do with being unchangeable rather than being important.

Option B : Unique - 'Unique' means being the only one of its kind, unlike anything else. This doesn't fit with the meaning of 'immutable.'

Option D : Awful - 'Awful' means very bad or unpleasant, and while decay might be perceived as unpleasant, this word does not convey the meaning of 'immutable' which is about being unchangeable.

Hence, Option C, "unchangeable," is the word that best expresses the meaning of the underlined word 'immutable' in the sentence.

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the word which best expresses the meaning of the underlined word in the sentence.
questions.content: It was an $$\underline {ignominious} $$ defect for the team.
questions.explanation:
Option A : Shameful - "Ignominious" is an adjective used to describe something that causes public disgrace or shame. "Shameful" also carries a similar meaning, suggesting something disgraceful or causing embarrassment. So, 'shameful' is indeed a synonym and correctly expresses the meaning of 'ignominious.'

Option B : Admirable - This is not a synonym for 'ignominious.' "Admirable" is used to describe something that deserves admiration or respect, which is the opposite of something that is disgraceful or shameful.

Option C : Unaccountable - "Unaccountable" means not able to be explained or understood, which does not correspond to the meaning of 'ignominious,' which has to do with disgrace or shame.

Option D : Worthy - This is also not a synonym for 'ignominious.' "Worthy" is used to describe something deserving effort, attention, or respect, which is contrary to the meaning of 'ignominious.'

So, Option A, "shameful," is the word that best expresses the meaning of the underlined word 'ignominious' in the sentence.

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the word which best expresses the meaning of the underlined word in the sentence.
questions.content: His $$\underline {conjecture} $$ was the better than mine.
questions.explanation:
Option A : guess

Explanation :

The word 'conjecture' refers to an opinion or conclusion formed on the basis of incomplete information, essentially, a hypothesis or an educated guess. So, in the given sentence, the term 'conjecture' could be suitably replaced with the word 'guess' without losing the original meaning.

Let's also consider the other options :

Option B : Fact - A 'fact' is something that is known to be true and can be proven. This contrasts with the term 'conjecture,' which refers to an opinion or conclusion based on incomplete information. Therefore, 'fact' is not a suitable replacement.

Option C : Surprise - A 'surprise' refers to an unexpected or astonishing event, fact, or thing. This doesn't align with the meaning of 'conjecture,' which has more to do with forming opinions or conclusions based on incomplete information.

Option D : Doubt - 'Doubt' refers to a feeling of uncertainty or lack of conviction. While conjectures may indeed stem from doubts, the two words aren't synonyms. 'Doubt' doesn't capture the aspect of forming a conclusion or opinion, which is integral to 'conjecture.'

Therefore, 'guess' (Option A) is the word that best expresses the meaning of the underlined word 'conjecture' in the sentence.

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.content: Freedom and quality are the ................ rights of every human.
questions.explanation:
The word "inalienable" means unable to be taken away or denied. When we say that freedom and quality are inalienable rights of every human, we mean that these rights are inherent to all people and should not be denied or taken away. This is a common phrase often used in discussions about human rights.

In contrast, "inscrutable" means hard to interpret or understand, "incalculable" means too great to be calculated or estimated, and "institutional" refers to something that is established as a norm or convention in an organization or culture. None of these words make sense in the context of your sentence about human rights.

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.content: Pradeep's face spoke .................. of the happiness he was feeling.
questions.explanation:
Option C : volumes

Explanation :

The expression "speak volumes" is an idiom in English, meaning to provide a lot of information, especially in an indirect or unspoken way. In the context of this sentence, "Pradeep's face spoke volumes of the happiness he was feeling" means that Pradeep's facial expressions gave away a great deal about his inner happiness, even if he didn't verbally express it.

Looking at the other options :

Option A : Elegantly - While one could argue that a face could "speak elegantly," this phrase is not a common idiom or phrase in English, and it doesn't quite capture the intended meaning of conveying a lot of information.

Option B : Tons - The word "tons" is used informally to mean a large amount, but it's typically used with countable or quantifiable things. It's not typically used in the context of someone's facial expressions communicating an emotion.

Option D: Much - While "much" does mean a large amount, it doesn't quite fit into this sentence naturally. It's not a commonly used phrase to say a face "spoke much" of an emotion.

Therefore, Option C, "volumes," is the best fit for this sentence.

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.content: His speech was disappointing : it ................ all the major issues.
questions.explanation:
Option A : "Projected"

"Projected" typically refers to the act of planning, estimating, or forecasting something for the future. It's often used in terms of estimating future performance or outcomes based on current data or trends. However, in the context of the sentence, "projected" doesn't fit because we're discussing a speech's handling of issues, not forecasting them.

Option B : "Revealed"

"Revealed" means to make known, disclose, or uncover something that was previously hidden or unknown. If the sentence read, "His speech was enlightening: it revealed all the major issues," then "revealed" would make sense. However, the sentence is about the speech being disappointing, and revealing issues would typically be seen as a positive thing.

Option C : "Skirted"

"Skirted" means to evade or avoid dealing with something. In the context of a speech, if someone "skirts" an issue, it means they are intentionally avoiding addressing it. Given that the sentence states the speech was disappointing, "skirted" is a fitting choice because a speech that avoids major issues can indeed be disappointing.

Option D : "Analysed"

"Analysed" means to examine in detail the structure of something, typically for purposes of interpretation or explanation. If a speech analysed all the major issues, it would typically be seen as thorough or comprehensive, not disappointing. Therefore, this word does not fit well in the given sentence.

So, considering the context of the sentence and the meaning of the word "disappointing," the word "skirted" fits best.

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the word which is closest to the opposite in meaning of the given italicised word.
questions.content: Hydra is biologically believed to be immortal.
questions.explanation:
Option A : "Undying"

"Undying" is actually a synonym of "immortal," not an antonym. Both words imply an ability to live forever or endure indefinitely.

Option B : "Perishable"

"Perishable" refers to something that is susceptible to decay, spoilage, or death. It is typically used to describe food or other goods that have a short lifespan before they become unusable or unsafe. This is the opposite of "immortal," which refers to something that can't die or decay.

Option C : "Ancient"

"Ancient" refers to something very old or that has existed for a very long time. However, it doesn't necessarily imply death or ending. While something ancient has been around for a long time, it might still be around today. So, it's not quite the opposite of "immortal."

Option D : "Eternal"

"Eternal" is another synonym of "immortal." Both words refer to something that lasts forever or has no end.

So, the term closest to the opposite in meaning to "immortal" is "perishable" (Option B), as it refers to something that will not last forever and is susceptible to ending or decay.

In the provided sentence, the italicized word "patronised" is used to mean that the Gupta rulers supported, sponsored, or promoted cultural activities.

Here 'Opposed' is the correct. Opposite meaning word to the given italicised word 'patronised'.

Patronised means provide favour or support.

Opposed means disagreeing with someone/something.

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the word which is closest to the opposite in meaning of the given italicised word.
questions.content: This is a barbarous act.
questions.explanation:
Option A : "Bad" - This word is used to describe something that is not good in terms of quality, standard, or performance. While "barbarous" certainly includes a negative connotation, it specifically refers to a lack of civilization or brutal behavior. So, while a "barbarous" act is generally "bad," these words are not direct opposites.

Option B : "Good" - This is a general term used to express approval or positive qualities in something. While "good" is generally the opposite of "bad," it doesn't directly contrast with "barbarous," which emphasizes brutality or uncivilized behavior more than just being bad.

Option C : "Civilised" - This word is used to describe societies that are well-organized and socially developed, typically with a high level of cultural, scientific, and technical achievement. It also can refer to behavior that is polite, refined, and respectful of others. In other words, "civilised" behavior is the opposite of "barbarous" behavior, which is often characterized by brutality, violence, and lack of advanced cultural and social systems.

Option D : "Exemplary" - This word is used to describe something that is a desirable model or very good example of a particular quality. Although "exemplary" could imply behavior that is the opposite of "barbarous," it doesn't necessarily contrast the uncivilized or brutal connotations of "barbarous" in the same direct way as "civilised." It's more about being a good example, which can encompass many behaviors beyond just the opposite of being barbarous.

Hence, out of all the options, "civilised" is the closest to being the opposite of "barbarous".

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: In the following question, out of the four alternatives, choose the one which can be substituted for the given words/sentence.
questions.content: A person who does not believe in any religion
questions.explanation:
Option C :

Atheist

Explanation :

The term 'Atheist' specifically refers to a person who does not believe in the existence of a god or any gods, and by extension, does not subscribe to any religion. This aligns with the phrase given "A person who does not believe in any religion."

Now, let's review the other options :

Option A : Philatelist - This term refers to a person who collects or studies stamps. It has no relation to belief or non-belief in religion.

Option B : Rationalist - While a rationalist, a person who bases their opinions and actions on reason and knowledge rather than on religious belief or emotional response, may not necessarily believe in any religion, the term doesn't inherently imply a lack of belief in any religion. Some rationalists might also subscribe to religious beliefs.

Option D : Pagan - Pagans are typically characterized as people holding religious beliefs other than those of the main world religions, rather than not believing in any religion. Paganism is a broad term that encompasses a variety of different religions, including ancient Roman and Greek religions.

Therefore, 'Atheist' is the most appropriate substitution for the phrase "A person who does not believe in any religion."

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: In the following question, out of the four alternatives, choose the one which can be substituted for the given words/sentence.
questions.content: A person who believes that pleasure is the chief good
questions.explanation:
Option B : Hedonist - A hedonist is a person who believes that the pursuit of pleasure is the most important thing in life; a pleasure-seeker. This fits perfectly as a substitution for the phrase "A person who believes that pleasure is the chief good".

Looking at the other options :

Option A : Stoic - A Stoic is a person who can endure pain or hardship without showing their feelings or complaining. This is not associated with the pursuit of pleasure as the chief good in life.

Option C : Epicure - An Epicure is a person who takes particular pleasure in fine food and drink. While this does involve a pursuit of pleasure, it's specifically about gourmet experiences, not pleasure in general.

Option D : Sensual - A sensual person primarily concerned with the gratification of the senses or appetites; they seek out experiences that provide sensory pleasure. While this does imply a focus on pleasure, it's not as all-encompassing as 'hedonist' which refers to a belief that pleasure is the chief good in life, across all forms of pleasure, not just sensory.

Therefore, 'Hedonist' is the correct choice for the substitution of the phrase "A person who believes that pleasure is the chief good".

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: In the following question, out of the four alternatives, choose the one which can be substituted for the given words/sentence.
questions.content: One who loves mankind
questions.explanation:
Option B : Philanthropist - A philanthropist is a person who seeks to promote the welfare of others, often through the donation of money, resources, or time to charitable causes. The root of the word, "phil-" comes from the Greek for love, and "-anthropist" comes from the Greek for human being, so it quite literally means "one who loves mankind".

For the other options :

Option A : Anthropologist - An anthropologist is a person who studies aspects of humans within past and present societies. While they might love mankind in a sense, the term doesn't imply this, it's about studying humans, not necessarily loving them.

Option C : Seismologist - A seismologist is a scientist who studies earthquakes and seismic waves. This term has no relevance to loving mankind.

Option D : Optometrist - An optometrist is a healthcare professional who provides primary vision care. This term also doesn't imply any particular love for mankind.

Therefore, 'Philanthropist' is the correct choice for the substitution of the phrase "One who loves mankind".

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the order of the sentences marked A, B, C, D and E to form a logical paragraph.
questions.content:
A. Tasty and healthy food can help you bring out their best.

B. One minute they are toddlers and next you see them in their next adventure.

C. Your young ones seem to be growing so fast.

D. Being their loving custodians, you always want to see them doing well.

E. Their eyes sparkle with curiosity and endless questions on their tongues.
questions.explanation:
1. Sentence C ("Your young ones seem to be growing so fast.") is a natural starting point because it establishes the subject of the paragraph: the rapid growth of children. This sentence sets the stage for the other sentences to build upon.

  2. Sentence B ("One minute they are toddlers and next you see them in their next adventure.") directly follows the theme of rapid growth from the previous sentence, emphasizing the quick progression from one stage of childhood to the next.

  3. Sentence E ("Their eyes sparkle with curiosity and endless questions on their tongues.") continues the narrative by describing a typical characteristic of growing children—their curiosity and desire to explore the world around them. It smoothly transitions from the idea of their "adventures" mentioned in sentence B.

  4. Sentence D ("Being their loving custodians, you always want to see them doing well.") transitions from the description of the children to the perspective of the caregivers. It introduces the role and the desires of the adults in the lives of the children.

  5. Sentence A ("Tasty and healthy food can help you bring out their best.") concludes the paragraph by offering a way caregivers can contribute to the children's wellbeing—by providing nutritious and delicious food. This sentence effectively ties back to the desires of the caretakers (sentence D) and brings the paragraph to a cohesive close.

So, the sequence CBEDA creates a coherent narrative about the growth of children and the caretakers' desire to contribute positively to that growth.

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the order of the sentences marked A, B, C, D and E to form a logical paragraph.
questions.content:
A. It is hoping that overseas friends will bring in big money and lift the morale of the people.

B. But a lot needs to be done to kick start industrial revival.

C. People had big hopes from the new government.

D. So far government has only given an incremental push to existing policies and programmes.

E. Government is to go for big time reforms, which it promised.
questions.explanation:
Option D : CDEAB

C. "People had big hopes from the new government." This sentence makes a good starting point because it introduces the context: people's expectations of the new government.

D. "So far government has only given an incremental push to existing policies and programmes." This sentence logically follows the first, as it addresses the actions taken by the new government in response to these expectations.

E. "Government is to go for big time reforms, which it promised." This is a forward-looking statement, indicating the government's future plans to fulfill the expectations (big hopes) of the people.

A. "It is hoping that overseas friends will bring in big money and lift the morale of the people." This continues the narrative of the government's plans, now specifying a strategy to attract foreign investment to boost morale.

B. "But a lot needs to be done to kick start industrial revival." This sentence wraps up the paragraph, emphasizing that, despite the government's plans and initiatives, there's still much work to be done.

Hence, the order CDEAB forms a logical and coherent paragraph.

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the order of the sentences marked A, B, C, D and E to form a logical paragraph.
questions.content:
A. However, women hiring is catching up at a slow and steady rate in the recent times.

B. Gender ratio has been inclined more towards male employees.

C. As a result, recent reports have highlighted the rise in demand for women employees.

D. Women constitute a little over half of world's total population.

E. But, their contribution to measured economic activity is far below the potential.
questions.explanation:
Option A : DEBAC

Explanation :

The logical flow of these sentences should start with a general fact (D), followed by a statement of the problem (E), an observation of the current scenario (B), the effects of that scenario (A), and finally the result (C). Here's how that looks :

D. Women constitute a little over half of the world's total population. (This sets the context with a general fact.)

E. But, their contribution to measured economic activity is far below the potential. (This indicates a problem or disparity.)

B. Gender ratio has been inclined more towards male employees. (This specifies the problem further.)

A. However, women hiring is catching up at a slow and steady rate in the recent times. (This indicates a change in the situation.)

C. As a result, recent reports have highlighted the rise in demand for women employees. (This describes the result of the change.)

Therefore, the correct answer is Option A (DEBAC). The other sequences do not logically connect the sentences to create a cohesive paragraph.

questions.subject: logical-reasoning
questions.content: The average age of 8 men is increased by 2 yrs. when one of them whose age is 20 yr is replaced by a new man. What is the age of the new man?
questions.explanation:
The average age of 8 men increased by 2 years when one of them, who is 20 years old, is replaced. This means the new man brought an additional 2 years to the average age for each of the 8 people, for a total of 2$$ \times $$8 = 16 additional years.

However, we have to remember that this is on top of the 20 years of the man he replaced. So, the age of the new man is 20 (the age of the replaced man) + 16 (additional years) = 36 years.

So, the correct answer is :

Option B : 36 yr

questions.subject: logical-reasoning
questions.content: Shikha is mother-in-law of Ekta who is sister-in-law of Ankit. Pankaj is father of Sanjay, the only brother of Ankit. How is Shikha related to Ankit?
questions.explanation:
The relation is as following

From the relationships given :

  1. Shikha is mother-in-law of Ekta, so Ekta is married to Shikha's son.
  2. Ekta is sister-in-law of Ankit, so Ankit is her husband's brother. Because Ekta is married to Shikha's son, this means Ankit is also Shikha's son.
  3. Pankaj is father of Sanjay, the only brother of Ankit, so Sanjay and Ankit are both sons of Pankaj. Because Ankit is Shikha's son, Pankaj is Shikha's husband.

So, Shikha is Ankit's mother.

Option D : Mother.

questions.content: If Re(z + 2) = | z $$-$$ 2 |, then the locus of z is
questions.explanation:

Re(z + 2) = | z $$-$$ 2 |

Re(x + iy + 2) = | x + iy $$-$$ 2 |

x + 2 = $$\sqrt {{{(x - 2)}^2} + {y^2}} $$

Squaring on both sides,

(x + 2)2 = (x $$-$$ 2)2 + y2

x2 + 4 + 4x = x2 + 4 $$-$$ 4x + y2 $$\Rightarrow$$ y2 = 8x

The locus of z is a parabola.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Which of the following is not an equivalence relation in z?

options.content: aRb $$ \Leftrightarrow $$ a + b is an even integer
aRb $$ \Leftrightarrow $$ a $$-$$ b is an even integer

questions.explanation:
Let R = {(a, b) : a + b is an even integer a, b $$\in$$ Z}

For a $$\in$$ Z, a + a = 2a is an even integer.

$$\therefore$$ (a, a) $$\in$$ R $$\forall$$ a $$\in$$ Z

$$\therefore$$ R is reflexive.

Let (a, b) $$\in$$ R $$\Rightarrow$$ a + b is an even integer.

$$\Rightarrow$$ (b + a) is an even integer $$\Rightarrow$$ (b, a) $$\in$$ R

$$\Rightarrow$$ R is symmetric.

Let (a, b), (b, c) $$\in$$ R

$$\Rightarrow$$ (a + b) and (b + c) are even integers.

$$\Rightarrow$$ (a + b) + (b + c) = (a + c + 2b) is an even integer.

$$\Rightarrow$$ (a + c + 2b) $$-$$ 2b = (a + c) is an even integer.

$$\Rightarrow$$ (a, c) $$\in$$ R is transitive.

$$\therefore$$ R is an equivalence relation.

Let R = {(a, b) : (a $$-$$ b) is an even integer, a, b $$\in$$ Z}.

For a $$\in$$ Z, a $$-$$ a = 0 is an even integer.

$$\therefore$$ (a, a) $$\in$$ R $$\forall$$ a $$\in$$ Z

$$\therefore$$ R is reflexive.

Let (a, b) $$\in$$ R $$\Rightarrow$$ (a $$-$$ b) is an even integer.

$$\Rightarrow$$ $$-$$ (a $$-$$ b) is an even integer.

$$\Rightarrow$$ (b $$-$$ a) is an even integer $$\Rightarrow$$ (b, a) $$\in$$R

$$\Rightarrow$$ R is symmetric.

Let (a, b), (b, c) $$\in$$R $$\Rightarrow$$ (a $$-$$ b), (b $$-$$ c) are even integers.

$$\Rightarrow$$ (a $$-$$ b) + (b $$-$$ c) is an even integer.

$$\Rightarrow$$ (a $$-$$ c) is an even integer.

$$\Rightarrow$$ (a, c) $$\in$$R

$$\Rightarrow$$ R is transitive.

$$\therefore$$ R is an equivalence relation.

Let R = {(a, b) : a < b, a, b$$\in$$Z}

Let a $$\in$$Z . a < a is false.

$$\therefore$$ R is not reflexive.

$$\therefore$$ R is not an equivalence relation.

Let R = {(a, b) : a = b, a, b $$\in$$Z}.

It is quite easy to check that R is an equivalence relation.

Since, $$t = {2^{ - x}} > 0\forall x \in R$$

As, 2x is an increasing function,

$$-$$x < 2 or x > $$-$$2

Solution is $$( - 2,\infty )$$.

questions.explanation:
$$\left| {\cot x} \right| = \cot x + {1 \over {\sin x}}$$

Let $$\cot x > 0 \Rightarrow \cot x = \cot x + {1 \over {\sin x}} = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over {\sin x}} = 0$$ which is not possible.

Let $$\cot x \le 0 \Rightarrow - \cot x = \cot x + {1 \over {\sin x}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow - 2\cot x = {1 \over {\sin x}} \Rightarrow \cos x = - {1 \over 2} \Rightarrow x = {{2\pi } \over 3},{{8\pi } \over 3}$$

$$\therefore$$ The number of solutions is 2.

questions.content: If x = 9 is the chord of contact of the hyperbola x2 $$-$$ y2 = 9, then the equation of the corresponding pair of tangent is
questions.explanation: x = 9 meets the hyperbola at (9, 6$$\sqrt2$$) and (9, $$-$$6$$\sqrt2$$). Then, the equations of tangent at these points are 3x $$-$$ 2$$\sqrt{2y}$$ $$-$$ 3 = 0. The combined equation of these two tangent is 9x2 $$-$$ 8y2 $$-$$ 18x + 9 = 0

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The points with position vectors $$10\widehat i + 3\widehat j$$, $$12\widehat i - 5\widehat j$$ and $$a\widehat i + 11\widehat j$$ are collinear, if a is
questions.explanation:
Let the points be $$A(10\widehat i + 3\widehat j)$$

$$B(12\widehat i - 5\widehat j)$$ and $$C(a\widehat i + 11\widehat j)$$.

$$AB = \left| {2\widehat i - 18\widehat j} \right|$$ and $$AC(a - 10)\widehat i + 8\widehat j$$

Since, A, B and C are collinear, then

$${2 \over {a - 10}} = - {{18} \over 8} \Rightarrow a = {{82} \over 9}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Let a, b, c be vectors of lengths 3, 4, 5 respectively and a be perpendicular to (b + c), b to (c + a) and c to (a + b), then the value of (a + b + c) is
questions.explanation:
We have, | a | = 3, | b | = 4 and | c | = 5.

It is given that

a $$ \bot $$ (b + c), b $$ \bot $$ (c + a) and c $$ \bot $$ (a + b)

$$\Rightarrow$$ a . (b + c) = 0, b . (c + a) = 0 and c . (a + b) = 0

$$\Rightarrow$$ a . b + a . c = b . c + b . a = c . a = c . b = 0

or, a . b + b . c + c . a = 0

(adding all the above equations)

Now, | a + b + c |2 = | a |2 + | b |2 + | c |2 + 2 (a . b + b . c + c . a)

= 32 + 42 + 52 = 50

$$\therefore$$ | a + b + c | = 5$$\sqrt2$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: For non-zero vectors a, b, c; |(a $$\times$$ b) . c| = |a| |b| |c| holds if and only if

options.content: a . b = b . c = c . a = 0

questions.explanation:
We have, $$\left| {(a \times b).\,c} \right| = \left| a \right|\left| b \right|\left| c \right|$$

$$ \Rightarrow \left\| a \right\|\left\| b \right\|\left| c \right|\left. {\sin \theta \cos \alpha } \right| = \left| a \right|\left| b \right|\left| c \right|$$

$$ \Rightarrow \left| {\sin \theta } \right|\left| {\cos \alpha } \right| = 1 \Rightarrow \theta = {\pi \over 2}$$ and $$\alpha = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow a \bot b$$ and $$c||\widehat n \Rightarrow a \bot b$$ and c $$\bot$$ both a and b.

$$\Rightarrow$$ a, b, c are mutually perpendicular.

$$\Rightarrow$$ a . b = b . c = c . a = 0

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Angle between the diagonals of a cube is
questions.explanation:
Let each edge of cube be a, then coordinates of the vertices of cube are

O(0, 0, 0), A(a, 0, 0), B(0, a, 0), C(0, 0, a), N(a, a, 0), P(a, a, a), L(0, a, a), M(a, 0, a)

Direction ratios of the diagonals OP, AL, BM and CN are (a, a, a), ($$-$$a, a, a), (a, $$-$$a, a) and (a, a, $$-$$a).

Let $$\theta$$ be the acute angle between diagonals OP and AL.

$$\therefore$$ $$\cos \theta = {{{a_1}{a_2} + {b_1}{b_2} + {c_1}{c_2}} \over {\sqrt {a_1^2 + b_1^2 + c_1^2} \sqrt {a_2^2 + b_2^2 + c_2^2} }}$$

$$ = {{a \times ( - a) + a \times a + a \times a} \over {\sqrt {{a^2} + {a^2} + {a^2}} \sqrt {{{( - a)}^2} + {a^2} + {a^2}} }}$$

$$ = {{ - {a^2} + {a^2} + {a^2}} \over {\sqrt {3{a^2}} \sqrt {3{a^2}} }} = {{{a^2}} \over {a\sqrt 3 \times a\sqrt 3 }}$$

$$ \Rightarrow \cos \theta = {1 \over 3} \Rightarrow \theta = {\cos ^{ - 1}}\left( {{1 \over 3}} \right)$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content:
Consider the two lines

$${L_1}:{{x + 1} \over 3} = {{y + 2} \over 1} = {{z + 1} \over 2}$$ and $${L_2}:{{x - 2} \over 1} = {{y + 2} \over 2} = {{z - 3} \over 3}$$

The unit vector perpendicular to both the lines L1 and L2 is
questions.explanation:
Given lines are

$${L_1}:{{x + 1} \over 3} = {{y + 2} \over 1} = {{z + 1} \over 2}$$ and $${L_2}:{{x - 2} \over 1} = {{y + 2} \over 2} = {{z - 3} \over 3}$$

Now, convert into vector form

$${L_1}:( - \widehat i - 2\widehat j - \widehat k) + \lambda (3\widehat i + \widehat j + 2\widehat k)$$

$${L_2}:(2\widehat i + 2\widehat j + 3\widehat k) + \mu (\widehat i + 2\widehat j + 3\widehat k)$$

Line L1 comparing with $${a_1} + \lambda {b_1}$$

and L2 comparing with $${a_2} + \mu {b_2}$$, then we have $${b_1} = 3\widehat i + \widehat j + 2\widehat k$$ and $${b_2} = \widehat i + 2\widehat j + 3\widehat k$$

Perpendicular to both b1 and b2 = $${b_1} \times {b_2}$$

$$ = \left| {\matrix{ {\widehat i} & {\widehat j} & {\widehat k} \cr 3 & 1 & 2 \cr 1 & 2 & 3 \cr } } \right|$$

$$ = \widehat i(3 - 4) - \widehat j(9 - 2) + \widehat k(6 - 1) = - \widehat i - 7\widehat j + 5\widehat k$$

$$\therefore$$ Required unit vector $$ = {{ - \widehat i - 7\widehat j + 5\widehat k} \over {\sqrt {{{( - 1)}^2} + {{( - 7)}^2} + {{(5)}^2}} }}$$

$$ = {{ - \widehat i - 7\widehat j + 5\widehat k} \over {\sqrt {75} }} = {{ - \widehat i - 7\widehat j + 5\widehat k} \over {5\sqrt 3 }}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The distance between the line $$r = 2\widehat i - 2\widehat j + 3\widehat k + \lambda (\widehat i - \widehat j + 4\widehat k)$$ and the plane $$a\,.\,(\widehat i + 5\widehat j + \widehat k) = 5$$ is
questions.explanation:
The given line is r = a + tb, where $$a = 2\widehat i - 2\widehat j + 3\widehat k$$, $$b = \widehat i - \widehat j + 4\widehat k$$ and given plane is r . n = d, where $$n = \widehat i + 5\widehat j + \widehat k$$, d = 5.

Since, $$b\,.\,n = 1 - 5 + 4 = 0$$

$$\therefore$$ Given line is parallel to given plane.

$$\therefore$$ The distance between the line and the plane is equal to length of the perpendicular from the point a = $${2\widehat i - 2\widehat j + 3\widehat k}$$ on the line to the given plane.

$$\therefore$$ Required distance $$ = \left| {{{(2\widehat i - 2\widehat j + 3\widehat k)\,.\,(\widehat i + 5\widehat j + \widehat k) - 5} \over {\sqrt {1 + 25 + 1} }}} \right|$$

$$ = \left| {{{2 - 10 + 3 - 5} \over {\sqrt {27} }}} \right| = {{10} \over {3\sqrt 3 }}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Two cards are drawn from a pack of 52 cards. What is the probability that either both are red or both are kings?
questions.explanation:
Let E1 = event of getting both red cards

E2 = event of getting both kings

and E1 $$\cap$$ E2 = event of getting 2 kings of red cards

$$\therefore$$ $$P({E_1}) = {{{}^{26}{C_2}} \over {{}^{52}{C_2}}} = {{325} \over {1326}}$$, $$P({E_2}) = {{{}^4{C_2}} \over {{}^{52}{C_2}}} = {6 \over {1326}}$$

and $$P({E_1} \cap {E_2}) = {{{}^2{C_2}} \over {{}^{52}{C_2}}} = {1 \over {1326}}$$

$$\therefore$$ P (both red or both kings) = $$P({E_1} \cap {E_2}) = P({E_1}) + P({E_2}) - P({E_1} \cap {E_2})$$

$$ = {{325} \over {1326}} + {6 \over {1326}} - {1 \over {1326}} = {{330} \over {1326}} = {{55} \over {221}}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If A and B are two independent events such that $$P(A) = {1 \over 2}$$ and $$P(B) = {1 \over 5}$$, then which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation:
Since, A and B are independent events.

$$\therefore$$ $$P(A/B) = P(A) = {1 \over 2} \Rightarrow P\left( {{A \over {A \cup B}}} \right) = {{P[A \cap (A \cup B)]} \over {P(A \cup B)}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow P\left[ {{A \over {A \cup B}}} \right] = {{P(A)} \over {P(A \cup B)}} = {{1/2} \over {{1 \over 2} + {1 \over 5} - {1 \over {10}}}}$$

$$ = {{1/2} \over {{1 \over 2} + {1 \over 5} - {1 \over {10}}}} = {{1/2} \over {{6 \over {10}}}} = {5 \over 6}$$

Similarly, $$P\left( {{{A \cap B} \over {A' \cup B'}}} \right) = P\left( {{{A \cap B} \over {(A \cup B)'}}} \right) = 0$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Box I contains 5 red and 2 blue balls, while box II contains 2 red and 6 blue balls. A fair coin is tossed. If it turns up head, a ball is drawn from box I, else a ball is drawn from box II. The probability ball drawn is from box I, if it is blue, is
questions.explanation:
Let E1 = coin shows head, E2 = coin shows tail, A = drawn ball is blue

$$P({E_1}) = {1 \over 2} = P({E_2})$$

P(A/E1) = Probability of drawing a blue ball from bag I = 2/7

$$P\left( {{A \over {{E_2}}}} \right)$$ = Probability of drawing a blue ball from bag II = $${6 \over 8}$$

By Baye's theorem, we have

$$P\left( {{{{E_1}} \over A}} \right) = {{P({E_1})P\left( {{A \over {{E_1}}}} \right)} \over {P({E_1})P\left( {{A \over {{E_1}}}} \right) + P({E_2})P\left( {{A \over {{E_2}}}} \right)}}$$

$$ = {{{1 \over 2} \times {2 \over 7}} \over {{1 \over 2} \times {2 \over 7} + {1 \over 2} \times {6 \over 8}}} = {{{2 \over 7}} \over {{2 \over 7} + {6 \over 8}}} = {2 \over 7} \times {{56} \over {58}} = {8 \over {29}}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: For a random variable X, E(X) = 3 and E(X2) = 11. The variable of X is :
questions.explanation:
Given, E(X) = 3 and E(X2) = 11

Variable of X = E(X2) $$-$$ [E(X)]2 = 11 $$-$$ 32 = 11 $$-$$ 9 = 2

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The sum of 10 items is 12 and the sum of their squares is 18, then the standard deviation will be
questions.explanation:
Given, x1 + x2 + x3 + .... + x10 = 12

and x$$_1^2$$ + x$$_2^2$$ + ..... + x$$_{10}^2$$ = 18

$${\sigma ^2} = {1 \over n}\sum {{x^2} - {{\left( {{1 \over n}\sum x } \right)}^2}} $$

$$ = {1 \over {10}} \times 18 - {\left( {{1 \over {10}} \times 12} \right)^2} = {9 \over 5} - {{36} \over {25}} = {9 \over {25}}$$

$$\therefore$$ Standard deviation = 3/5.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The height of the chimney when it is found that on walking towards it 50 m in the horizontal line through its base, the angle of elevation of its top changes from 30$$^\circ$$ to 60$$^\circ$$ is :
questions.explanation:
Let PQ be the chimney whose height is h meters.

In $$\Delta$$BPQ, $$\tan 60^\circ = {{PQ} \over {BP}} \Rightarrow \sqrt 3 = {h \over x} \Rightarrow h = \sqrt 3 x$$ ..... (i)

and in $$\Delta$$APQ, $$\tan 30^\circ = {{PQ} \over {AP}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over {\sqrt 3 }} = {h \over {50 + x}} \Rightarrow 50 + x = h\sqrt 3 $$

$$ \Rightarrow 50 + x = 3x \Rightarrow x = 25$$ [using Eq. (i)]

$$\therefore$$ Height of the chimney = $$25\sqrt 3 $$ m

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The value of $$\mathop {\lim }\limits_{x \to 0} {{\sqrt {1 - {{\cos x}^2}} } \over {1 - \cos x}}$$ is
questions.explanation:
The required limit

$$ = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{x \to 0} {{\sqrt {(1 - \cos {x^2})(1 + \cos {x^2})} } \over {(1 - \cos x)\sqrt {1 + \cos {x^2}} }}$$

$$ = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{x \to 0} {{\left( {{{\sin {x^2}} \over {{x^2}}}} \right)} \over {2\left( {{{{{\sin }^2}x/2} \over {{x^2}}}} \right)}}.{1 \over {\sqrt {1 + \cos {x^2}} }} = {1 \over {2 \times {1 \over 4} \times \sqrt 2 }} = \sqrt 2 $$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If $$f(x) = \left\{ {\matrix{ {a{x^2} + 1,} & {x \le 1} \cr {{x^2} + ax + b,} & {x > 1} \cr } } \right.$$ is differentiable at x = 1, then
questions.explanation:
$$f'(1 - 0) = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{h \to 0} {{f(1 - h) - f(1)} \over { - h}}$$

$$ = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{h \to 0} {{a{{(1 - h)}^2} + 1 - (1 + a)} \over { - h}} = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{h \to 0} {{a({h^2} - 2h)} \over { - h}} = 2a$$

$$f'(1 + 0) = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{h \to 0} {{f(1 + h) - f(1)} \over h}$$

$$ = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{h \to 0} {{{{(1 + h)}^2} + a(1 + h) + b - (1 + a)} \over h}$$

$$ = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{h \to 0} {{{h^2} + 2h + ah + b} \over h} = 2 + a$$, if b = 0

Thus, $$2a = 2 + a,b = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow a = 2,b = 0$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The slope of the tangent to the curve x = t2 + 3t $$-$$ 8, y = 2t2 $$-$$ 2t $$-$$ 5 at the point t = 2 is
questions.explanation:
We have, $${{dx} \over {dt}} = 2t + 3$$ and $${{dy} \over {dt}} = 4t - 2$$

$$\therefore$$ $${{dy} \over {dx}} = {{dy/dt} \over {dx/dt}} = {{4t - 2} \over {2t + 3}}$$

Thus, slope of the tangent to the curve at the point t = 2 is

$${\left[ {{{dy} \over {dx}}} \right]_{t = 2}} = {{4(2) - 2} \over {2(2) + 3}} = {6 \over 7}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: $$\int {{1 \over {1 - 2\sin x}}dx} $$ is equal to
questions.explanation:
Let $$I = \int {{1 \over {1 - 2\sin x}}dx} $$

On putting $$\sin x = {{2\tan {x \over 2}} \over {1 + {{\tan }^2}{x \over 2}}}$$, we get

$$I = \int {{1 \over {1 - {{4\tan {x \over 2}} \over {1 + {{\tan }^2}{x \over 2}}}}}dx = \int {{{1 + {{\tan }^2}{x \over 2}} \over {1 + {{\tan }^2}{x \over 2} - 4\tan {x \over 2}}}dx} } $$

$$ = \int {{{{{\sec }^2}{x \over 2}} \over {1 + {{\tan }^2}{x \over 2} - 4\tan {x \over 2}}}dx} $$

$$ = 2\int {{1 \over {{{\left( {\tan {x \over 2} - 2} \right)}^2} - {{(\sqrt 3 )}^2}}}d\left( {\tan {x \over 2}} \right)} $$

$$ = 2\int {{{dt} \over {{{(t - 2)}^2} - {{(\sqrt 3 )}^2}}}} $$, where $$t = \tan {x \over 2}$$

$$ = 2\,.\,{1 \over {2\sqrt 3 }}\log \left| {{{t - 2 - \sqrt 3 } \over {t - 2 + \sqrt 3 }}} \right| + c = {1 \over {\sqrt 3 }}\log \left| {{{\tan {x \over 2} - 2 - \sqrt 3 } \over {\tan {x \over 2} - 2 + \sqrt 3 }}} \right| + c$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: $$\int\limits_0^1 {{{\log (1 + x)} \over {1 + {x^2}}}dx} $$ is equal to :
questions.explanation:
Let $$I = \int_0^1 {{{\log (1 + x)} \over {1 + {x^2}}}dx = \int_0^{\pi /4} {{{\log (1 + \tan \theta )} \over {(1 + {{\tan }^2}\theta )}}{{\sec }^2}\theta d\theta } } $$

Let $$x = \tan \theta \Rightarrow dx = {\sec ^2}\theta d\theta $$

$$ = \int_0^{\pi /4} {\log (1 + \tan \theta )d\theta = \int_0^{\pi /4} {\log \left[ {1 + \tan \left( {{\pi \over 4} - \theta } \right)} \right]d\theta } } $$

$$ = \int_0^{\pi /4} {\log \left( {1 + {{1 - \tan \theta } \over {1 + \tan \theta }}} \right)d\theta } $$

$$ = \int_0^{\pi /4} {\log \left( {{2 \over {1 + \tan \theta }}} \right)d\theta = \log 2\int_0^{\pi /4} {1d\theta - I} } $$

$$ \Rightarrow 2I = {\pi \over 4}\log 2 \Rightarrow I = {\pi \over 8}\log 2$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The area of one curvilinear triangle formed by curves y = sin x, y = cos x and X-axis, is
questions.explanation:
Required area

$$\int_0^{\pi /4} {\sin xdx + \int_{\pi /4}^{\pi /2} {\cos xdx} } $$

$$ = - [\cos ]_0^{\pi /4} + [\sin x]_{\pi /4}^{\pi /2} = 2\left( {1 - {1 \over {\sqrt 2 }}} \right) = (2 - \sqrt 2 )$$ sq units

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Solution of $$\left( {{{x + y - 1} \over {x + y - 2}}} \right){{dy} \over {dx}} = \left( {{{x + y + 1} \over {x + y + 2}}} \right)$$, given that y = 1 when x = 1 is
questions.explanation:
$$\left( {{{x + y - 1} \over {x + y - 2}}} \right){{dy} \over {dx}} = \left( {{{x + y + 1} \over {x + y + 2}}} \right)$$

Put $$x + y = v$$

$$\therefore$$ $$1 + {{dy} \over {dx}} = {{dv} \over {dx}}$$ or $$\left( {{{v - 1} \over {v - 2}}} \right)\left( {{{dv} \over {dx}} - 1} \right) = \left( {{{v + 1} \over {v + 2}}} \right)$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{dv} \over {dx}} - 1 = {{(v + 1)(v - 2)} \over {(v - 1)(v + 2)}} = {{{v^2} - v - 2} \over {{v^2} + v - 2}}$$ or $${{dv} \over {dx}} = {{2{v^2} - 4} \over {({v^2} + v - 2)}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{({v^2} + v - 2)} \over {({v^2} - 2)}}dv = 2dx \Rightarrow \left( {1 + {v \over {{v^2} - 2}}} \right)dv = 2dx$$

On integrating, we get

$$v + {1 \over 2}\log \left| {{v^2} - 2} \right| = 2x + c$$

or, $$(y - x) + {1 \over 2}\log \left| {{{(x + y)}^2} - 2} \right| = c$$

Given, y = 1 when x = 1

$$\therefore$$ $$0 + {1 \over 2}\log 2 = c$$ or $$(y - x) + {1 \over 2}\log \left| {{{{{(x + y)}^2} - 2} \over 2}} \right| = 0$$

or, $$\log \left| {{{{{(x + y)}^2} - 2} \over 2}} \right| = 2(x - y)$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If $$y = \sin \left( {2{{\tan }^{ - 1}}\sqrt {{{1 - x} \over {1 + x}}} } \right)$$, then $${{dy} \over {dx}}$$ is :
questions.explanation:
Given, $$y = \sin \left( {2{{\tan }^{ - 1}}\sqrt {{{1 - x} \over {1 + x}}} } \right)$$

Let $$x = \cos 2\theta \Rightarrow y = \sin \left( {2{{\tan }^{ - 1}}\sqrt {{{1 - \cos 2\theta } \over {1 + \cos 2\theta }}} } \right)$$

$$ \Rightarrow y = \sin \left( {2{{\tan }^{ - 1}}\sqrt {{{2{{\sin }^2}\theta } \over {2{{\cos }^2}\theta }}} } \right) \Rightarrow y = \sin [2{\tan ^{ - 1}}(\tan \theta )]$$

$$ \Rightarrow y = \sin 2\theta \Rightarrow y = \sqrt {1 - {{\cos }^2}2\theta } \Rightarrow y = \sqrt {1 - {x^2}} $$

$$\therefore$$ $${{dy} \over {dx}} = {1 \over {2\sqrt {1 - {x^2}} }}( - 2x) = - {x \over {\sqrt {1 - {x^2}} }}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The maximum value of the function y = x(x $$-$$ 1)2, is
questions.explanation:
We have, $$y = x{(x - 1)^2}$$

$$\therefore$$ $${{dy} \over {dx}} = {(x - 1)^2}\,.\,1 + 2x(x - 1) = 3{x^2} - 4x + 1 = (x - 1)(3x - 1)$$

For maximum or minimum, $${{dy} \over {dx}} = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow (x - 1)(3x - 1) = 0 \Rightarrow x = {1 \over 3},1$$

Now, $${{{d^2}y} \over {d{x^2}}} = 6x - 4 \Rightarrow {\left[ {{{{d^2}y} \over {d{x^2}}}} \right]_{x = {1 \over 3}}} = - 2 < 0$$

$$\therefore$$ y is maximum when $$x = {1 \over 3}$$ and maximum value is

$${[y]_{x = {1 \over 3}}} = {4 \over {27}}$$

Also, $${\left[ {{{{d^2}y} \over {d{x^2}}}} \right]_{x = 1}} = 2 > 0$$

$$\therefore$$ y is minimum when x = 1.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The solution of $${x^3}{{dy} \over {dx}} + 4{x^2}\tan y = {e^x}\sec y$$ satisfying y (1) = 0, is
questions.explanation:
We have, $$\cos y{{dy} \over {dx}} + {4 \over x}\sin y = {{{e^x}} \over {{x^3}}}$$

Let $$\sin y = t$$

$$ \Rightarrow \cos y{{dy} \over {dx}} = {{dt} \over {dx}}$$ $$\therefore$$ $${{dt} \over {dx}} + {4 \over x}t = {{{e^x}} \over {{x^3}}}$$

$$IF = {e^{\int {{4 \over x}dx} }} = {e^{4\log x}} = {x^4}$$

The solution is

$$\therefore$$ $$t{x^4} = \int {{x^4}\,.\,{{{e^x}} \over {{x^3}}}dx = x{e^x} - {e^x} + c} $$ $$\because$$ $$\sin y\,{x^4} = x{e^x} - {e^x} + c$$

$$\because$$ x = 1, y = 0 [$$\because$$ c = 0]

$$\therefore$$ $$\sin y = {e^x}(x - 1){x^{ - 4}}$$

The runs of two players for 10 innings each are as follows

The more consistent player is
questions.explanation:
Let us make the table from the given data

Player A Player B
$${x_i}$$ $${x_i} - 61$$ $${({x_i} - 61)^2}$$ $${y_i}$$ $${y_i} - 61$$ $${({y_i} - 61)^2}$$
58 $$ - $$3 9 94 33 1089
59 $$ - $$2 4 26 $$ - $$35 1225
60 $$ - $$1 1 92 31 961
54 $$ - $$7 49 65 4 16
65 4 16 96 35 1225
66 5 25 78 17 289
52 $$ - $$9 81 14 $$ - $$47 2209
75 14 196 34 $$ - $$27 729
69 8 64 98 37 1369
52 $$ - $$9 81 13 $$ - $$48 2304
$$\sum {{x_i} = 610} $$ $$\sum {{{({x_i} - 61)}^2} = 526} $$ $$\sum {{y_i} = 610} $$ $$\sum {{{({y_i} - 61)}^2} = 11416} $$

For player A, Mean = $${{\sum {{x_i}} } \over n} = {{610} \over {10}} = 61$$

$$SD = \sqrt {{{\sum {{{({x_i} - 61)}^2}} } \over N}} $$

$$ = \sqrt {{{526} \over {10}}} = 7.25$$

For player B, Mean = $${{\sum {{y_i}} } \over n} = {{610} \over {10}} = 61$$

$$SD = \sqrt {{{\sum {{{({y_i} - 61)}^2}} } \over N}} $$

$$ = \sqrt {{{11416} \over {10}}} = 33.79$$

Since, SD for player A is 7.25 < SD for player B is 33.79.

Hence, player A is more consistent player.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Find the area enclosed by the loop in the curve 4y2 = 4x2 $$-$$ x3.
questions.explanation:
Substitute 0 for y in the equation 4y2 = 4x2 $$-$$ x3,

0 = x2(4 $$-$$ x) $$\Rightarrow$$ x = 0, x = 4

It means curve makes the loop symmetric about X-axis between 0 and 4.

Area $$ = 2\int_0^4 {ydx = {2 \over 2}\int_0^4 {\sqrt {4{x^2} - {x^3}} dx = \int_0^4 {x\sqrt {4 - x} \,dx} } } $$

Let $$4 - x = t \Rightarrow - dx = dt$$

Area $$ = - \int_4^0 {(4 - t)\sqrt t \,dt} $$

$$ = \int_0^4 {(4\sqrt t - t\sqrt t )dt = \left[ {4 \times {2 \over 3}{t^{3/2}} - {2 \over 5}{t^{5/2}}} \right]_0^4} $$

$$ = {8 \over 3} \times 8 - {2 \over 5} \times 32 = {{64} \over 3} - {{64} \over 5} = 64 \times {2 \over {15}} = {{128} \over {15}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
An ideal monoatomic gas is taken round the cycle ABCDA as shown in the p-diagram

The work done during the cycle is
questions.explanation:
Work done in the cyclic process

= Area of the loop ABCD

= (2p $$-$$ p) $$\times$$ (2V $$-$$ V) = pV

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The initial speed of a body of mass 2.0 kg is 5 m/s. A force acts for 4 s in the direction of motion of the body, as shown in force-time graph. The impulse of force is
questions.explanation:
Impulse of a force = Area between the force-time graph

Hence, impulse of force = area of $$\Delta$$OA'A + area of rectangle A'B'BA + area of trapezium BB'C'C + area of rectangle CC'ED

$$ = {1 \over 2} \times 1.5 \times 3 + 1 \times 3 + {1 \over 2}(3 + 2)(3 - 2.5) + 2 \times 1$$

$$ = 2.25 + 3 + 1.25 + 2$$

$$ = 8.50$$ Ns

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: For a constant hydraulic stress on an object, the fractional change in the object's volume $$\left( {{{\Delta V} \over V}} \right)$$ and its bulk modulus B are related as
questions.explanation:
Bulk modulus $$ = {{Hydraulic\,stress} \over {Volumetric\,strain}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow B = {{Hydraulic\,stress} \over {{{\Delta V} \over V}}}$$

or, $${{\Delta V} \over V} = $$ Hydraulic stress $$ \times {1 \over B}$$

$$\therefore$$ For constant hydraulic stress, $${{\Delta V} \over V} \propto {1 \over B}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A shunt is connected in parallel with a galvanometer. Why?

options.content: To prevent galvanometer from strong current
To increase the range of ammeter

questions.explanation: A shunt is a low resistance which is connected in parallel with a galvanometer (or ammeter) to protect it from large current and to increase the range of ammeter.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The phase difference between Vout and Vin of CE amplifier circuit is
questions.explanation: There is a phase difference of 180$$^\circ$$ between the signal voltage and output voltage in a common emitter amplifier. It is also known as phase reversal.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: If nth division of main scale coincides with (n + 1)th division of vernier scale. The least count of the vernier is (Given, one main scale division is equal to a units)
questions.explanation:
(n + 1) divisions of vernier scale = n division of main scale

$$\therefore$$ 1 VSD = $${n \over {n + 1}}$$ MSD

Least count = 1 MSD $$-$$ 1 VSD

= 1 MSD $$-$$ $${n \over {n + 1}}$$ MSD = $${1 \over {n + 1}}$$ MSD

= $${1 \over {n + 1}}$$ $$\times$$ a units = $${a \over {n + 1}}$$ units [$$\because$$ given, 1 MSD = a units]

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
A uniform rod AB of length L = 1 m is sliding along two mutually perpendicular surfaces OP and OQ as shown in the figure.

When the rod subtends an angle $$\theta$$ = 30$$^\circ$$ with OQ, the end B has a velocity $$\sqrt3$$ m/s. The velocity of end A at that time is
questions.explanation:
According to the question,

Let OB = x, OA = y and x = L cos$$\theta$$

So, by Pythagoras theorem,

$$\Rightarrow$$ x2 + y2 = L2

Differentiating w.r.t. 't', we get

$$2x{{dx} \over {dt}} + 2y{{dy} \over {dt}} = 0$$

$$2x{v_B} + 2y{v_A} = 0$$ [$$\because$$ $${{dx} \over {dt}} = {v_B}$$ and $${{dy} \over {dt}} = {v_A}$$]

$$ \Rightarrow {v_A} = - {x \over y}{v_B}$$

$$ \Rightarrow \left| {{v_A}} \right| = {x \over y}{v_B} = {v_B}\cot \theta $$ [$$\because$$ $${x \over y} = \cot \theta $$]

$$ = \sqrt 3 \times \cot 30^\circ $$

$$ = \sqrt 3 \times {1 \over {\sqrt 3 }}$$ = 1 m/s

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
A tray of mass (M) 12 kg is supported by a spring as shown in the figure.

When the tray is pressed down and released, it executes SHM with a period of 1.5 s. When a block of mass m placed on the tray, the period of SHM changes to 3.0 s. The mass of block is
questions.explanation:
Let k be the force constant of spring.

Time period, $$T = 2\pi \sqrt {{M \over k}} $$ ...... (i)

When block of mass m is placed in the tray, the time period of oscillations becomes

$$T' = 2\pi \sqrt {{{M + m} \over k}} $$ ...... (ii)

On dividing Eq. (ii) by Eq. (i), we get

$$ \Rightarrow {{T'} \over T} = {{\sqrt {M + m} } \over {\sqrt M }}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {3 \over {1.5}} = \sqrt {{{12 + m} \over {12}}} $$ [given, M = 12 kg, T = 1.5 s, T' = 3 s]

$$ \Rightarrow \sqrt {{{12 + m} \over {12}}} = 2$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ 12 + m = 48

$$\Rightarrow$$ m = 36 kg

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The phasor diagram of a load represents which circuit?

options.content: R-L-C circuit with X<sub>L</sub> more than X<sub>C</sub>
R-L-C circuit with X<sub>L</sub> less than X<sub>C</sub>

questions.explanation:
As shown in phasor diagram, voltage leads the current.

As in purely inductive circuit, current lags behind the voltage by an angle of 90$$^\circ$$, here angle is not 90$$^\circ$$ but it is lesser than that.

So, this type of case arise in R-L-C circuit when R-L-C load with inductive reactance is more than the capacitive reactance as shown below.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The equation of progressive wave is given by $$Y = \sin \left[ {x\left( {{t \over 5} - {x \over 9}} \right) + {\pi \over 6}} \right]$$ cm. Which one of the following is correct?
questions.explanation:
Given,

$$Y = \sin \left[ {x\left( {{t \over 5} - {x \over 9}} \right) + {\pi \over 6}} \right]$$ ...... (i)

The general equation of progressive wave is

$$Y = A\sin \left[ {2\pi \left( {{t \over T} - {x \over \lambda }} \right) + \phi } \right]$$ ...... (ii)

On comparing Eq. (i) with Eq. (ii), we get

A = 1 cm, f = 0.1 Hz, v = 1.8 cm/s and $${{2\pi } \over \lambda } = {\pi \over 9}$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ $$\lambda$$ = 18 cm

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The property of light used in optical fibre cables is
questions.explanation: In fibre optic communication, signals are transmitted through an optical fibre. The property of light used in transmission through optical fibre cables is total internal reflection.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A man walks in a straight line for 5 min with a velocity of 45 m/s. What is the speed with which he has to move in order to comeback to its original position in 1.5 min?
questions.explanation:
Distance moved by man in 5 min with velocity of 45 m/s is

Distance = Speed $$\times$$ Time

45 m/s $$\times$$ (5 $$\times$$ 60) s = 13500 m

When he move back, it covers the same distance to come back to its original position.

Now, time taken = 1.5 min

= 1.5 $$\times$$ 60 s = 90 s

Distance travelled = 13500 m

$$\therefore$$ Speed $$ = {{distance} \over {Time}} = {{13500} \over {90}} = 150$$ m/s

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
From a solid sphere of mass M and radius R, a spherical portion of radius $${R \over 2}$$ is removed as shown in the figure.

Taking gravitational potential V = 0 at r = $$\infty$$, the potential at the centre of the cavity thus formed is
questions.explanation:
Potential at point P due to the solid sphere,

$${V_1} = - {{GM} \over {2{R^3}}}\left[ {3{R^2} - {{\left( {{R \over 2}} \right)}^2}} \right]$$

$$ = - {{11GM} \over {8R}}$$

Potential at point P due to the cavity part,

$${V_2} = - {3 \over 2}{{G\left( {{M \over 8}} \right)} \over {{R \over 2}}} = - {{3GM} \over {8R}}$$

Potential due to the remaining part at point P,

$$V = {V_1} - {V_2} = {{ - 11GM} \over {8R}} + {{3GM} \over {8R}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow V = - {{GM} \over R}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Four charges equal to + Q are placed at the four corners of a square and a charge ($$-$$q) is at its centre. If the system is in equilibrium, then the value of $$-$$q is
questions.explanation:
Consider the equilibrium of charge Q at corner A

$${F_B} = {F_D} = {1 \over {4\pi {\varepsilon _0}}}{{{Q^2}} \over {{a^2}}} = {{k{Q^2}} \over {{a^2}}}$$ [$$\because$$ $${1 \over {4\pi {\varepsilon _0}}} = k$$]

$${F_C} = {{k{Q^2}} \over {{{(\sqrt 2 a)}^2}}}$$ [$$\because$$ $$AC = \sqrt 2 a$$]

$$ = {{k{Q^2}} \over {2{a^2}}}$$

$${F_O} = {{k\,Qq} \over {{{\left( {{a \over {\sqrt 2 }}} \right)}^2}}} = {{k\,2Qq} \over {{a^2}}}$$ [$$\because$$ $$OC = {a \over {\sqrt 2 }}$$]

For equilibrium of charge Q at corner A, the net force on this charge along AC must be zero.

$$\therefore$$ $${F_O} = {F_C} + {F_B}\cos 45^\circ + {F_D}\cos 45^\circ $$

$$ = {F_C} + 2{F_B}\cos 45^\circ $$ [$$\because$$ $${F_B} = {F_D}$$]

$$ = {F_C} + 2{F_B} \times {1 \over {\sqrt 2 }}$$ [$$\because$$ $$\cos 45^\circ = {1 \over {\sqrt 2 }}$$]

$$ \Rightarrow {{k\,2Qq} \over {{a^2}}} = {{k\,{Q^2}} \over {2{a^2}}} + {{2 \times k{Q^2}} \over {{a^2}}} \times {1 \over {\sqrt 2 }}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 2Qq = {{{Q^2}} \over 2} + {{{Q^2}} \over {\sqrt 2 }} \times 2$$

$$ \Rightarrow 2q = {Q \over 2} + Q\sqrt 2 $$

$$ \Rightarrow q = {Q \over 4}(1 + 2\sqrt 2 )$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A force F = a + bx acts on a particle in the x-direction where a and b are constants. The work done by this force during a displacement from x = 0 to x = d is
questions.explanation:
Work done by the particle in X-direction is given by

dW = F dx = (a + bx) dx

Total work done in displacement from x = 0 to x = d will be

$$W = \int {dW = \int\limits_0^d {(a + bx)dx} } $$

$$ = \left[ {ax + {{b{x^2}} \over 2}} \right]_0^d$$

$$ \Rightarrow W = \left( {a + {{bd} \over 2}} \right)d$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A proton has kinetic energy E = 100 eV which is equal to that of a photon. The wavelength of photon is $$\lambda$$2 and that of proton is $$\lambda$$1. The ratio $${{{\lambda _2}} \over {{\lambda _1}}}$$ is proportional to
questions.explanation:
Kinetic energy of a proton is given by

$$E = {1 \over 2}{m_p}v_p^2$$

$$ \Rightarrow E = {{{p^2}} \over {2{m_p}}}$$ [$$\because$$ $$p = mv$$]

$$\therefore$$ Wavelength of proton is, $${\lambda _1} = {h \over p}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {\lambda _1} = {h \over {\sqrt {2{m_p}E} }}$$ ..... (i)

Now, energy of photon is given by

$$E = h{v_2} \Rightarrow E = {{hc} \over {{\lambda _2}}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {\lambda _2} = {{hc} \over E}$$ ....... (ii)

where, $$\lambda$$2 is wavelength of photon.

On dividing Eq. (ii) by Eq. (i), we get

$${{{\lambda _2}} \over {{\lambda _1}}} = {{hc} \over E} \times {{\sqrt {2{m_p}E} } \over h}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{\lambda _2}} \over {{\lambda _1}}} = {c \over {\sqrt E }}\sqrt {2{m_p}} $$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{\lambda _2}} \over {{\lambda _1}}} \propto {E^{ - 1/2}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A block of mass 10 kg rests on a rough inclined plane making an angle of 30$$^\circ$$ with the horizontal. The coefficient of static friction between the block and the plane is 0.1. The friction force on the block is
questions.explanation:
The FBD of the block of mass 10 kg is

For the equilibrium of block, the frictional force must balanced the sine component of mg.

$$\therefore$$ f = mg sin 30$$^\circ$$

$$ = 10 \times 9.8 \times {1 \over 2} = 49$$ N

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Which of the following graphs show the correct relation between conductivity and temperature for a metallic conductor?
questions.explanation:
Conductivity ($$\sigma$$) of a metallic conductor is given by

$$\sigma = {1 \over \rho } = {{n{e^2}\tau } \over m}$$

where, $$\rho$$ = resistivity of conductor,

$$\tau$$ = relaxation time,

n = number of free electrons

and m = mass.

For metals, as the temperature increases, the relaxation time $$\tau$$ decreases because collisions become more frequent. Hence, the conductivity of a metallic conductor decreases with the increases of temperature.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The radius of a muonic hydrogen atom is 2.5 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$13 m. The total atomic volume (in m3) of a mole of such hydrogen atoms is (Take, $$\pi$$ = 3.14)
questions.explanation:
Given, radius of hydrogen atom, r = 2.5 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$13 m

Volume of one atom, $$V = {4 \over 3}\pi {r^3}$$

Number of atoms in 1 mole = 6.023 $$\times$$ 1023

Volume of 1 mole of H-atoms = $$N \times {4 \over 3}\pi {r^3}$$

$$ = 6.023 \times {10^{23}} \times {4 \over 3} \times 3.14 \times {(2.5 \times {10^{ - 13}})^3}$$

$$ = 3.94 \times {10^{ - 14}}$$ m3

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The angular momentum of a body placed at origin of mass 1 kg and having position vector $$r = 3t\widehat i + 4\widehat j$$ is
questions.explanation:
Given, m = 1 kg, $$r = 3t\widehat i + 4\widehat j$$

Velocity of body, $$v = {{dr} \over {dt}}$$

$$ = {d \over {dt}}(3t\widehat i + 4\widehat j) \Rightarrow v = 3\widehat i$$

Angular momentum, $$L = m(r \times v)$$

$$ = 1 \times [(3t\widehat i + 4\widehat j) \times 3\widehat i]$$

$$ = \left| {\matrix{ {\widehat i} & {\widehat j} & {\widehat k} \cr {3t} & 4 & 0 \cr 3 & 0 & 0 \cr } } \right|$$

$$ = [3t \times 0 - 4 \times 3]\widehat k$$

$$ \Rightarrow L = - 12\widehat i$$ J-s

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: If the earth stops rotating about its axis, then what will be the change in the value of g at a place in the equatorial plane? (Radius of earth = 6400 km)
questions.explanation:
The value of g at equator is expressed as

$${g_e} = g - R{\omega ^2}\cos \phi = g - R{\omega ^2}$$ [$$\because$$ $$\cos \phi = 1$$]

$$\Rightarrow$$ Change in value of g is $$g - {g_e}$$

$$ = R{\omega ^2} = R{\left( {{{2\pi } \over T}} \right)^2}$$

$$ = 6.4 \times {10^6} \times {\left[ {{{2\pi } \over {24 \times 60 \times 60}}} \right]^2}$$

$$ = 3.37 \times {10^{ - 2}}$$ m/s2

$$ \simeq 3.4$$ cm/s2

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
Two cars approach a stationary observer from opposite sides as shown in the figure.

The observer hears no beats. If the frequency of the horn of the car B is 504 Hz, then the frequency of the horn of the car A will be
questions.explanation:
Apparent frequency of car A = Apparent frequency of car B

$$ \Rightarrow {v \over {v - {v_s}}} imes u = {v \over {v - v{'_s}}} imes u '$$

$$ \Rightarrow { u \over {v - 15}} = {{504} \over {v - 30}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow u = {{340 - 15} \over {340 - 30}} imes 504$$ [$$ ecause$$ velocity of sound in air is 340 m/s]

$$ \Rightarrow u = 529.2$$ Hz

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In the following circuit, assuming point A to be at zero potential, then what is the potential at point B?
questions.explanation:
Using Kirchhoff's loop law, in loop BDCR1 B, we get

2 $$\times$$ 2 + 3R1 = 4 or R1 = 0

$$\therefore$$ Potential drop at B = Potential drop at C

$$\Rightarrow$$ VB = VC = 2 + VA

= 2 + 0 [$$\because$$ VA = 0, given]

$$\Rightarrow$$ VB = 2 V

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
Two plane mirrors A and B are aligned parallel to each other as shown in the figure.

A ray of light is incident at an angle 30$$^\circ$$ at a point just inside one end of A. The plane of incidence coincides with the plane of the figure. The maximum number of times, the ray undergoes reflection (excluding the first one) before it emerges out is
questions.explanation:
Let N be the maximum number of reflection that ray undergoes.

Suppose it covers x distance in one reflection, then

$$Nx = 2\sqrt 3 $$

$$ \Rightarrow N = {{2\sqrt 3 } \over x} = {{2\sqrt 3 } \over {0.2\,\tan 30^\circ }}$$ [$$\because$$ $$x = 0.2\,\tan 30^\circ $$]

$$N = {6 \over {0.2}} = 30$$

Number of reflections ray undergoes before it emerges excluding the first one are N $$-$$ 1

$$ = 30 - 1 = 29$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A projectile is given an initial velocity of $$(\widehat i + \widehat j)$$ m/s, where, $$\widehat i$$ is along the ground and $$\widehat j$$ is along the vertical. If g = 10 m/s2, then the equation of its trajectory is
questions.explanation:
According to equation of motion, in vector form,

$$v = u - gt\,.\,\widehat j$$

$$ \Rightarrow v = \widehat i + \widehat j - 10t\,\widehat j$$

Integrating w.r.t. 't' both sides, we get

$$r = \int {v\,dt = \int {(\widehat i + \widehat j - 10t\,\widehat j)\,dt} } $$

or, $$x\widehat i + y\widehat j = t\widehat i + t\widehat j - 5{t^2}\widehat j$$

$$\therefore$$ On comparing, we get

$$x = t$$

and $$y = t - 5{t^2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow y = x - 5{x^2}$$

This is the required equation of trajectory of particle.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two drops of equal radius (R) coalesce to form a bigger drop. What is the ratio of surface energy of bigger drop to smaller one?
questions.explanation:
Volume of bigger drop = Volume of two smaller drops

$$ \Rightarrow {4 \over 3}\pi R{'^3} = 2 \times {4 \over 3}\pi {R^3}$$

where, R' is the radius of bigger drop.

$$ \Rightarrow R{'^3} = 2{R^3}$$

$$ \Rightarrow R' = {2^{1/3}}\,R$$

Initial surface energy of two small drops, $${U_1} = 8\pi {R^2}\sigma $$ ..... (i)

Final surface energy of big drop, $${U_2} = 4\pi R{'^2}\sigma $$

$$ = 4\pi \times {2^{2/3}}{R^2}\sigma $$ ..... (ii)

On dividing Eq. (ii) by Eq. (i), we get

$${{{U_2}} \over {{U_1}}} = {{4\pi \times {2^{2/3}}\,{R^2}\sigma } \over {8\pi {R^2}\sigma }} = {{{2^{2/3}}} \over 2} = {{{2^{ - 1/3}}} \over 1}$$

Ratio of surface energy of bigger drop to smaller one is 2$$-$$1/3 : 1.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two particles A and B of masses mA and mB respectively, are having same charge and moving on same plane. A uniform magnetic field exists perpendicular to this plane. The speeds of the particles are vA and vB respectively and the trajectories are as shown in figure. Then,
questions.explanation:
Force on charge particle in magnetic field is balanced by centripetal force, so $${{m{v^2}} \over r} = qvB\sin 90^\circ $$

[$$\theta$$ = 90$$^\circ$$, therefore magnetic field is perpendicular]

$${{m{v^2}} \over r} = qvB$$ [sin90$$^\circ$$ = 1]

$$ \Rightarrow r = {{mv} \over {qB}}$$

For both particles, q and B are same.

Therefore, r $$\propto$$ mv

or, $${{{r_A}} \over {{r_B}}} = {{{m_A}{v_A}} \over {{m_B}{v_B}}}$$

As, rA > rB [given]

$$ \Rightarrow {m_A}{v_A} > {m_B}{v_B}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The potential difference applied to an X-ray tube is decreased. As a result, in the emitted radiation,
questions.explanation:
Minimum wavelength for X-ray is given by

$${\lambda _{\min }} = {{12375} \over V}\mathop A\limits^o $$

As the accelerating voltage V is decreased, $$\lambda$$min increases. The intensity of emitted radiation is determined by the number of electrons bombarding the target.

$$\therefore$$ Accelerating voltage does not change the intensity of X-rays emitted.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The ratio of the specific heats $${{{C_v}} \over {{C_p}}} = {1 \over \gamma }$$ in terms of degrees of freedom (n) is given by
questions.explanation:
As we know,

$${C_v} = {n \over 2}R$$ ...... (i)

$${C_p} = \left( {{n \over 2} + 1} \right)R$$ ..... (ii)

On dividing Eq. (ii) by Eq. (i), we get

$${{{C_p}} \over {{C_v}}} = \gamma = {{\left( {{n \over 2} + 1} \right)} \over {{n \over 2}}} = 1 + {2 \over n}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{C_p}} \over {{C_v}}} = 1 + {2 \over n}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A cyclist speeding at 6 m/s in a circle of 18 m radius makes an angle $$\theta$$ with the vertical. The minimum possible value of coefficient of friction between the tyres and the ground is
questions.explanation:
Given, v = 6 m/s, r = 18 , g = 9.8 m/s2

Now, the velocity of cyclist is given by

v2 = rg tan$$\theta$$

or, $$\tan \theta = {{{v^2}} \over {rg}} = {{6 \times 6} \over {18 \times 9.8}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow \tan \theta = 0.2041$$

The minimum value of coefficient of friction, $$\mu$$ = tan$$\theta$$

$$ \Rightarrow \mu = 0.2041$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Three particles each of mass m are kept at the vertices of an equilateral triangle of side b. Moment of inertia of the system about an axis passing through the centroid and perpendicular to its plane is
questions.explanation:
Let us consider an equilateral $$\Delta$$ABC of side b.

From figure,

In $$\Delta$$AOD,

$$\cos 30^\circ = {{AD} \over {AO}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{\sqrt 3 } \over 2} = {{{b \over 2}} \over r}$$ [$$\because$$ $$\cos 30^\circ = {{\sqrt 3 } \over 2}$$]

$$ \Rightarrow r = {b \over 2} \times {2 \over {\sqrt 3 }} = {b \over {\sqrt 3 }}$$

Moment of inertia about line passing through centroid,

$$I = 3 \times m{r^2}$$ [due to 3 masses present in system]

$$ \Rightarrow 3 \times m \times {\left( {{b \over {\sqrt 3 }}} \right)^2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow I = m{b^2}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: An electric dipole is placed at an angle of 30$$^\circ$$ in a non-uniform electric field. The dipole will experience

options.content: translational force only in the direction of the field
translational force only in a direction normal to the direction of the field
torque as well as a translational force

questions.explanation:
When a dipole is placed in a non-uniform electric field, opposite charges of the dipole experiences a force due to E. It is as shown in the figure below

These forces will act in opposite direction. Now, since the electric field is not uniform, so the force experienced by the charges will be unequal.

Hence, their will be a net force acting on the dipole, as they do not cancel each other.

Also, forces on the charges are not linear as shown above. So, they will experience a not non-zero torque. Hence, the dipole will experience both translational force and torque in a non-uniform electric field.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two coils A and B have a mutual inductance 0.001 H. The current changes in the first coil according to the equation $$i = {i_0}\sin \omega t$$, where i0 = 10A and $$\omega$$ = 10$$\pi$$ rads$$-$$1. The maximum value of emf in the second coil is
questions.explanation:
Induced emf, $$\varepsilon = - M{{di} \over {dt}}$$

where, i is given as, $$i = {i_0}\sin \omega t$$

$$ \Rightarrow \varepsilon = - M{d \over {dt}}[{i_0}\sin \omega t]$$

$$ = M\,{i_0}\omega \cos \omega t$$

For maximum value of emf in second coil, cos $$\omega$$t is maximum, i.e., 1.

$${E_{\max }} = M\,{i_0}\omega $$ [$$\because$$ $$\cos \omega t = 1$$]

$$ \Rightarrow 0.001 \times 10 \times 10\pi $$

$$ \Rightarrow {E_{\max }} = 0.1$$ $$\pi$$V

Hence, maximum emf value induced in second coil is 0.1 $$\pi$$V.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The current in the circuit will be
questions.explanation:
Diode D1 does not conduct because it is connected in reversed biased position.

Hence, only D2 conducts as it is forward biased.

$$\therefore$$ Current in circuit is given by

$$i = {V \over R}$$

$$ = {5 \over {30 + 20}} = {5 \over {20}}A \Rightarrow i = 0.1A$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
The bob of a pendulum of length 2 m lies at P, when it reaches Q, it losses 10% of its total energy due to air resistance.

The velocity of bob at Q is
questions.explanation:
Kinetic energy at Q = 90% of potential energy at P

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over 2}m{v^2} = {{90} \over {100}} \times mgh$$

$$ \Rightarrow v = \sqrt {1.8\,gh} \Rightarrow v = \sqrt {1.8 \times 10 \times 2} $$

$$ \Rightarrow v = 6$$ m/s

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A particle executes SHM with a frequency f. The frequency with which its kinetic energy oscillates is
questions.explanation:
Let displacement, x = A$$\omega$$ sin $$\omega$$t

Velocity, $$v = {{dx} \over {dt}} = A\omega \cos \omega t$$

Kinetic energy of particle in SHM,

$$K = {1 \over 2}m{v^2} \Rightarrow K = {1 \over 2}m{\omega ^2}{A^2}{\cos ^2}\omega t$$

$$ = {1 \over 2}m{\omega ^2}{A^2}\left( {{{1 + \cos 2\omega t} \over 2}} \right)$$ [$$\because$$ $${\cos ^2}\theta = {{1 + \cos 2\theta } \over 2}$$]

$$ = {1 \over 4}m{\omega ^2}{A^2}(1 + \cos 2\omega t)$$

$$\therefore$$ New angular frequency, $${\omega _K} = 2\omega $$

$$\therefore$$ Frequency of oscillation of kinetic energy = 2f [$$\because$$ $$f = {\omega \over {2\pi }}$$]

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A radioactive sample at any instant has its disintegration rate 5000 disintegrations per min. After 5 min, the rate is 1250 disintegrations per min. Then, the disintegration constant (per min) is
questions.explanation:
According to law of radioactivity, the rate of disintegration is given as

$$R = \lambda N = \lambda {N_0}{e^{ - \lambda t}}$$

Given, $$R = 5000$$

$$ \Rightarrow 5000 = \lambda {N_0}{e^{ - \lambda t}}$$ ...... (i)

After 5 min, $$R = 1250$$

$$\therefore$$ $$1250 = \lambda {N_0}{e^{ - \lambda (t + 5)}}$$ ...... (ii)

On dividing Eq. (i) by Eq. (ii), we get

$${{5000} \over {1250}} = {{{e^{ - \lambda t}}} \over {{e^{ - \lambda (t + 5)}}}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 4 = {e^{5\lambda }}$$

Taking log both sides, we get

$${\log _e}4 = {\log _e}({e^{5\lambda }})$$

$$ \Rightarrow lo{g_e}4 = 5\lambda \Rightarrow \lambda = {1 \over 5}{\log _e}{2^2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow \lambda = 0.4{\log _e}2$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The separation between two parallel plates of capacitor is 1 mm. What is the electric potential generates between the plates of capacitor, when electric field of 2000 N/C is applied on it?
questions.explanation:
In a uniform electric field, potential difference across two parallel plates of capacitor,

$$V = Ed$$

where, E is electric field and d is separation between plates.

$$ \Rightarrow V = 2000 \times (1 \times {10^{ - 3}}) = 2V$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Choose the correct statement.

options.content: The speed of light in the meta-material is $$v = c|n|$$.
The speed of light in the meta-material is $$v = {c \over {|n|}}$$.
The speed of light in the meta-material is v = c.
The wavelength of the light in the meta-material ($$\lambda$$<sub>m</sub>) is given by $$\lambda$$<sub>m</sub> = $$\lambda$$<sub>air</sub> | n |.

questions.explanation:
When light travel in meta-material, physical characteristics remain unchanged.

$$\therefore$$ $$v = {c \over {|n|}}$$

where, | n | is the relative refractive index of meta-material.

As, $$n = {c \over v} \Rightarrow |n| = {{{n_{med}}} \over {{n_{air}}}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow \left| n \right| = {{{\lambda _{air}}} \over {{\lambda _{med}}}} \Rightarrow {\lambda _{med}} = {{{\lambda _{air}}} \over {\left| n \right|}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A T-shaped object with dimensions shown in figure, is lying on a smooth floor. A force F is applied at the point P parallel to AB, such that the object has only the translational motion without rotation. Find the location of P with respect to C.
questions.explanation:
Let O be the centre of mass of part AB and Q that of CD. Let M be the mass per unit length of the parts AB and CD.

As, no rotation is set up about point P, so

moment of part AB about P = moment of part CD about P

or, (ml) x = (2 ml) (I $$-$$ x) [$$\because$$ $$m = {M \over I}$$]

or, x = 2I $$-$$ 2x

or, x = 2I / 3

Distance of P from the end C = 2I $$-$$ 2I/3 = 4I/3
